newsitem.title: USA: CME live cattle end mostly down, Aug sets new high.
newsitem.headline: CME live cattle end mostly down, Aug sets new high.

text.p: CME live cattle futures closed mostly lower on profit taking, but August posted a new contract high on support from strong cash markets and rolling of short positions into back months, traders said.
August live cattle set a new contract high of 69.900 cents and closed strong, up 0.375 at 69.875 cents. Other months finished 0.225 lower to unchanged.

Spot August continued to show strength following the record feedlot trade this week as well as the outlook for tighter showlists the next few weeks and an expected bullish cattle-on-feed report Friday, traders said.
"The record (feedlot) movement is bullish and the cattle (on feed) report is also expected to be constructive," one trader said.

Texas Panhandle/western Oklahoma feedlots reported a record 141,600 head weekly trade and Kansas a record 118,000 head for the week. Early estimates on the report averaged 86.2 percent for total August 1 on-feed numbers in the seven major feedlot states. July placement estimates averaged 110.5 percent and July marketings 102.4 percent.
Backs eased on profit taking from an overbought condition and heavy placement estimates were also negative, they said.

Refco and Cargill Investor Services bought August on the advance but selling by Cargill Investor Services and R.J. O'Brien later capped the market. Refco and Lind-Waldock sold October while spreaders sold October and December and hedgers sold December, pit sources said.

In live cattle options, volatility was weak on selling of at- and out-of-the-money calls in October and December early. Hedging interest, selling puts and buying calls was cited in February late, pit sources added.
Feeder cattle ended mixed as short covering generally offset pressure from higher corn futures, traders said.

November paced the recovery after being very oversold Tuesday on its late limit break. Stone Traders notably sold November. Scattered commission house short covering supported other months, they said.
The latest CME feeder cattle index was up $0.35 at 62.92 per cwt.
Feeder cattle closed 0.200 cent lower to 0.500 higher with October up 0.275 at 63.450 cents.
